question:
The art of decoration, called Pietra dura became popular during whose reign?

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The art of Pietra Dura (also called Parchin Kari in India) became widely popular during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628–1658).
  • It is a technique of inlaying finely cut and polished semi-precious stones into marble to form beautiful floral, geometric, or symbolic designs.
  • This decorative style was imported from Italy and adapted by Indian artisans under Mughal patronage.
  • Taj Mahal is the finest example where Pietra Dura is used extensively, especially on the cenotaphs of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal.
  • Other monuments like Itimad-ud-Daulah's tomb (started under Jahangir but completed with similar inlay work) also show early forms of this art.
  • The stones used include lapis lazuli, agate, jasper, turquoise, carnelian, and more — all fitted with extreme precision.
  • Pietra Dura symbolises the luxury, perfectionism, and refined aesthetics of Mughal architecture under Shah Jahan’s rule.

question:
Who among the following Mughal emperors built Sheesh Mahal in Agra?

SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The Sheesh Mahal (Mirror Palace) in Agra Fort was built by Emperor Shah Jahan.
  • It was constructed around 1631–1640 as part of the royal private quarters inside the fort.
  • The structure is famous for its intricate mirror work, with glass mosaics and polished marble reflecting light artistically.
  • It was primarily used as a pleasure palace or retreat for the royal family and is located close to the Mussamman Burj, where Shah Jahan was later imprisoned.
  • The decoration of Sheesh Mahal reflects Shah Jahan’s love for luxury and architectural refinement.
  • The palace showcases elements of Persian and Mughal styles, including multi-foil arches, floral carvings, and delicate ornamentation.
  • Today, Sheesh Mahal is considered one of the finest examples of mirror inlay work in Mughal architecture.

question:
Jama Masjid in Delhi was built by ___________.

SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The Jama Masjid in Delhi was built by Emperor Shah Jahan, one of the greatest patrons of Mughal architecture.
  • Its construction began in 1650 and was completed in 1656, taking around 6 years.
  • It was originally called Masjid-i-Jahan-Numa, meaning “World-reflecting Mosque”.
  • Located in Old Delhi, near the Red Fort, it is one of the largest mosques in India.
  • The mosque was built using red sandstone and white marble, showcasing a blend of Persian and Indian styles.
  • Jama Masjid served not only as a religious centre but also as a symbol of Mughal imperial power and urban planning.
  • Even today, it remains an important religious, historical, and architectural landmark.

question:
Which among the following was the son of the Mughal emperor Shahjahan?

SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Aurangzeb was the son of Mughal emperor Shah Jahan and his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
  • He was born in 1618 and was one of Shah Jahan's four prominent sons: Dara Shikoh, Shah Shuja, Murad Baksh, and Aurangzeb.
  • After a bloody war of succession following Shah Jahan’s illness in 1657, Aurangzeb emerged victorious by defeating and eliminating his brothers.
  • He imprisoned Shah Jahan in the Agra Fort, where the latter remained until his death in 1666.
  • Aurangzeb became the sixth Mughal emperor in 1658 and ruled for nearly 50 years, marking the longest reign among Mughal rulers.
  • His reign saw massive territorial expansion, but also growing instability due to strict religious policies.

question:
Ahmadnagar was finally annexed by the Mughals in __________.

SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Ahmadnagar Sultanate, located in the Deccan region, had long resisted Mughal expansion.
  • The Mughal attempts to annex it began during Akbar’s reign and continued under Jahangir and Shah Jahan.
  • Although Mughal forces had captured much of Ahmadnagar earlier, the final and complete annexation occurred in 1632 during Shah Jahan’s reign.
  • The decisive campaign was led by Khan Jahan Lodi (initially) and later completed by Prince Aurangzeb, who was appointed viceroy of the Deccan.
  • With this annexation, the Mughals gained control over key forts and territories, significantly strengthening their presence in the south.
  • This victory was a turning point in the Mughal policy of Deccan consolidation.

question:
Who among the following is credited with building Delhi's Lal Quilā (Red Fort)?

SSC CHSL 30/05/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Red Fort (Lal Quilā) in Delhi was commissioned and built by Emperor Shah Jahan.
  • Construction began in 1638 when Shah Jahan decided to shift the Mughal capital from Agra to Shahjahanabad (now Old Delhi).
  • The fort was completed in 1648 and served as the main residence of the Mughal emperors for around 200 years.
  • It was built using red sandstone, which gives the fort its iconic name.
  • The Red Fort showcases a grand blend of Persian, Timurid, and Indian architectural styles.
  • Key structures within the fort include Diwan-i-Aam, Diwan-i-Khas, Rang Mahal, and Moti Masjid.
  • Today, the Red Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a symbol of India’s national identity.

question:
Who among the following had written the book 'Char Chaman', during the reign of Shah Jahan, describing the Mughal nobility?

SSC CGL 16/08/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The book ‘Char Chaman’ was written by Chandrabhan Brahman, a prominent scholar and poet in the Mughal court during the reign of Shah Jahan.
  • He served as a munshi (secretary) and held an important position in the imperial administration.
  • The work Char Chaman (meaning “Four Gardens”) is written in Persian and provides detailed observations about Mughal nobility, court life, and administrative affairs.
  • Chandrabhan’s writings reflect his deep knowledge of Persian culture and literary elegance, blended with his unique Indian perspective.
  • The book is considered an important source of information on Mughal society and courtly etiquette during Shah Jahan’s time.
  • Unlike many Persian writers of the period, Chandrabhan was a Hindu Brahmin, which makes his viewpoint especially significant in Mughal historiography.

question:
Who among the following had been given the title of 'Sultan Buland Iqbal' by Shah Jahan?

SSC CPO 25/11/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• The title ‘Sultan Buland Iqbal’, meaning “The Sultan of Lofty Fortune”, was given by Emperor Shah Jahan to his eldest son, Dara Shikoh.
  • Dara was Shah Jahan’s favourite son and was groomed as his political heir.
  • He held high positions in the Mughal court and was entrusted with key administrative and military responsibilities.
  • The title reflected Shah Jahan’s trust in Dara and his elevated status among the Mughal princes.
  • Despite his prominence, Dara was defeated by his brother Aurangzeb during the war of succession and was later executed in 1659.
  • Dara is also remembered for his liberal religious views and efforts to bridge Islam and Hinduism, notably through translations of Hindu scriptures into Persian.

question: Shah Jahan ascended the Mughal throne in the year:
solution:
• Shah Jahan, whose real name was Prince Khurram, ascended the Mughal throne in the year 1628.
  • He became the fifth Mughal emperor after the death of his father, Emperor Jahangir, in 1627.
  • Though Jahangir died in 1627, Shah Jahan’s formal coronation took place in 1628 after overcoming rivals in the war of succession.
  • His reign (1628–1658) is considered the golden age of Mughal architecture, with monuments like the Taj Mahal, Red Fort, and Jama Masjid built during this period.
  • Shah Jahan also expanded the empire significantly, though his later years saw political instability due to internal family conflict.

question: What was Shah Jahan's name before ascending the throne?
solution:
• Before ascending the throne, Shah Jahan was known by his birth name Prince Khurram.
  • He was the third son of Emperor Jahangir and his Rajput wife Jagat Gosain.
  • The name “Shah Jahan” meaning “King of the World” was adopted after his coronation in 1628.
  • As Prince Khurram, he had already distinguished himself in military campaigns, particularly in the Deccan and against the Portuguese.
  • His talents and loyalty initially earned him favour in the court, especially from Jahangir and Nur Jahan, before political tensions emerged.
  • The transformation from Prince Khurram to Shah Jahan marked the beginning of one of the most culturally and architecturally rich periods in Mughal history.

question: Shah Jahan is best remembered in Indian history for his:
solution:
• Shah Jahan is most famously remembered in Indian history for his exceptional patronage of architecture.
  • His reign (1628–1658) marked the zenith of Mughal architectural achievement, often called the Golden Age of Mughal architecture.
  • He commissioned several iconic monuments, the most famous being the Taj Mahal, built in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
  • Other grand structures from his reign include the Red Fort (Lal Qila) in Delhi, Jama Masjid, and parts of Agra Fort.
  • Shah Jahan’s architectural style is noted for its extensive use of white marble, symmetrical design, pietra dura inlay work, and Persian-influenced aesthetics.
  • His focus on architecture reflected the Mughal ideal of combining imperial grandeur with artistic refinement.

question: Which Mughal monument is considered the finest example of Indo-Islamic architecture under Shah Jahan?
solution:
• The Taj Mahal is widely regarded as the finest example of Indo-Islamic architecture built under the patronage of Emperor Shah Jahan.
  • It was constructed between 1632 and 1653 in Agra, in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal, who died in 1631.
  • The structure combines Persian, Islamic, and Indian architectural elements, making it the perfect synthesis of Indo-Islamic style.
  • It is built entirely of white marble and adorned with Pietra Dura inlay, intricate carvings, and detailed calligraphy from the Quran.
  • The Taj Mahal’s symmetry, dome, minarets, gardens, and reflecting pool demonstrate unmatched precision and aesthetic harmony.
  • Recognised as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, it is considered one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.
  • The monument symbolises both eternal love and the pinnacle of Mughal architectural excellence.

question: The Taj Mahal was built in memory of:
solution:
• The Taj Mahal was built by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal.
  • Mumtaz Mahal, originally named Arjumand Banu Begum, died in 1631 while giving birth to their 14th child.
  • Deeply grieved by her death, Shah Jahan commissioned the construction of this grand mausoleum in Agra.
  • The construction began in 1632 and was completed around 1653, involving thousands of artisans and labourers.
  • The Taj Mahal stands as a symbol of eternal love and is considered the finest example of Mughal architecture.
  • Built using white marble with inlay work of semi-precious stones, it reflects a fusion of Persian, Islamic, and Indian styles.
  • It is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the most visited monuments in the world.

question: Shah Jahan’s reign is often described as the:
option_1: Beginning of Mughal decline
option_2: Golden Age of Mughal architecture
option_3: Rise of Rajput power
option_4: Period of strict orthodoxy
solution:
• Shah Jahan’s reign (1628–1658) is often described as the Golden Age of Mughal architecture.
  • During this period, the Mughal Empire reached aesthetic and architectural heights never seen before.
  • Shah Jahan was a passionate patron of art and architecture, commissioning iconic structures like the Taj Mahal, Red Fort, Jama Masjid, and Shah Jahan’s additions to Agra Fort.
  • His architectural style is noted for its use of white marble, symmetry, pietra dura inlay work, and Persian-influenced floral motifs.
  • This period also saw the refinement of garden design, mosques, and palaces that symbolised imperial grandeur and artistic excellence.
  • Due to this cultural and architectural flourish, his rule is remembered as the pinnacle of Mughal artistic achievement, especially in the field of monumental architecture.
  • While his reign was marked by internal peace and prosperity, it eventually ended with a war of succession, but his contributions to architecture remain unparalleled.

question: Shah Jahan built the Red Fort in which city?
solution:
• The Red Fort, also known as Lal Qila, was built by Emperor Shah Jahan in the city of Delhi.
  • Construction began in 1638 when Shah Jahan decided to shift the Mughal capital from Agra to Shahjahanabad (present-day Old Delhi).
  • The fort was completed in 1648 and served as the main residence of the Mughal emperors for nearly 200 years.
  • Built primarily of red sandstone, the fort is an outstanding example of Mughal military and palace architecture.
  • Key structures inside include the Diwan-i-Aam, Diwan-i-Khas, Rang Mahal, Moti Masjid, and Hammams.
  • The Red Fort symbolises Mughal imperial power and architectural excellence, and is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
  • Every year on 15th August, the Prime Minister of India hoists the national flag at the fort, marking its continued national importance.

question: The Peacock Throne, an extravagant symbol of Mughal royalty, was commissioned by:
solution:
• The Peacock Throne was commissioned by Emperor Shah Jahan as a symbol of imperial grandeur and Mughal supremacy.
  • It was constructed around 1635 and was placed in the Diwan-i-Khas (Hall of Private Audience) in the Red Fort, Delhi.
  • The throne was encrusted with gold, precious gems, and featured two jeweled peacocks standing behind it, giving it its name.
  • It was among the most luxurious thrones ever created, reportedly costing more than twice the cost of the Taj Mahal.
  • The throne symbolised the absolute authority and divine right of the Mughal emperor to rule.
  • In 1739, it was looted and taken away by Nadir Shah of Persia during his invasion of Delhi.
  • Though the original no longer survives, the Peacock Throne remains an iconic emblem of Mughal opulence in history.

question: Who was the chief architect of the Taj Mahal?
solution:
• The chief architect of the Taj Mahal was Ustad Isa, a renowned Persian architect.
  • He is credited with the design and architectural planning of the monument commissioned by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of Mumtaz Mahal.
  • Ustad Isa was assisted by a large team of artisans, engineers, and craftsmen from across Persia, Central Asia, and India.
  • The construction of the Taj Mahal began in 1632 and was largely completed by 1653, involving over 20,000 workers.
  • The design combines Persian, Islamic, and Indian architectural styles, and Ustad Isa played a key role in creating its iconic symmetry and elegance.
  • Though some historians suggest multiple architects may have contributed, Ustad Isa’s name is most prominently associated with the monument’s architectural brilliance.
  • The Taj Mahal is considered one of the greatest masterpieces of world heritage architecture.

question: Shah Jahan’s long illness in the 1650s led to a war of succession between his sons. Which son finally captured the throne?
solution:
• In the 1650s, Emperor Shah Jahan suffered a long illness, which triggered a war of succession among his four sons: Dara Shikoh, Aurangzeb, Shah Shuja, and Murad Baksh.
  • Dara Shikoh was the eldest and Shah Jahan’s chosen successor, but he lacked military and political support.
  • Aurangzeb, known for his ambition and military skill, formed alliances (notably with Murad) and defeated his brothers one by one.
  • Aurangzeb ultimately defeated Dara Shikoh at the Battle of Samugarh (1658) and had him executed in 1659.
  • After imprisoning Shah Jahan in the Agra Fort, Aurangzeb ascended the throne in 1658 and ruled until 1707.
  • His reign was the longest of any Mughal emperor and marked a period of territorial expansion and strict orthodoxy.

question: Shah Jahan was imprisoned in his final years in:
solution:
• In the final years of his life, Shah Jahan was imprisoned in the Agra Fort by his son Aurangzeb.
  • This occurred after the war of succession, in which Aurangzeb defeated all his brothers and took the throne in 1658.
  • Shah Jahan spent the last eight years (1658–1666) of his life confined in a section of Agra Fort, known as the Mussamman Burj or Jasmine Tower.
  • From his prison chamber, Shah Jahan had a clear view of the Taj Mahal, the mausoleum he had built for his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
  • He died in 1666, and was later buried beside Mumtaz Mahal in the Taj Mahal.
  • His imprisonment is one of the most poignant episodes in Mughal history, symbolising the personal tragedy behind imperial grandeur.

question: Which son of Shah Jahan was known for his liberal ideas and interest in Sufism?
solution:
• Dara Shikoh, the eldest son of Shah Jahan, was known for his liberal religious views and deep interest in Sufism.
  • He was a devoted follower of the Qadiri Sufi order and maintained close relations with several Sufi saints and scholars.
  • Dara sought to bridge the gap between Hinduism and Islam, believing in the essential unity of religions.
  • He translated Upanishads and the Bhagavad Gita from Sanskrit into Persian, hoping to make Hindu philosophy accessible to Muslim audiences.
  • His major work, “Majma-ul-Bahrain” (The Mingling of Two Oceans), explored the similarities between Vedantic and Sufi thought.
  • Although he was Shah Jahan’s favourite and chosen successor, his unorthodox views and lack of military strength led to his defeat and execution by Aurangzeb in 1659.

question: Shah Jahan's rule saw the Mughal Empire reach its peak in:
option_3: Military conquest and cultural achievements
solution:
• During the reign of Shah Jahan (1628–1658), the Mughal Empire reached its peak in terms of military power and cultural achievements.
  • His rule marked political stability, administrative refinement, and territorial expansion, particularly in the Deccan region.
  • The Mughal military under Shah Jahan carried out successful campaigns in Central India, the Deccan, and parts of modern-day Afghanistan.
  • However, Shah Jahan is best known for his contributions to architecture, such as the Taj Mahal, Red Fort, and Jama Masjid, making this era the golden age of Mughal architecture.
  • His reign also witnessed advancements in literature, painting, garden design, and court culture, reflecting the height of Mughal cultural sophistication.
  • These combined military successes and artistic achievements made Shah Jahan’s period the apex of Mughal imperial glory.

question: Shah Jahan moved the capital from Agra to:
solution:
• Shah Jahan moved the Mughal capital from Agra to Delhi, where he established a new city called Shahjahanabad.
  • This shift took place around 1638, driven by Shah Jahan's desire to create a new imperial capital reflecting Mughal grandeur.
  • Shahjahanabad, located in present-day Old Delhi, became the political and cultural centre of the Mughal Empire.
  • He commissioned the construction of grand structures like the Red Fort (Lal Qila) and the Jama Masjid in this new capital.
  • The city was planned with wide roads, markets like Chandni Chowk, gardens, and palatial residences.
  • Shahjahanabad remained the Mughal capital until the fall of the empire in the 19th century.

question: Which mosque built by Shah Jahan is one of the largest in India?
solution:
• The Jama Masjid in Delhi, built by Emperor Shah Jahan, is one of the largest mosques in India.
  • Construction began in 1650 and was completed in 1656, involving over 5,000 artisans.
  • The mosque was originally named Masjid-i-Jahan-Numa, meaning “Mosque reflecting the world”.
  • It can accommodate over 25,000 worshippers in its courtyard, making it one of the most spacious religious structures of the Mughal era.
  • Built using red sandstone and white marble, it showcases the grandeur of Mughal architecture, with three large domes and two minarets standing 40 metres high.
  • Jama Masjid is located in Shahjahanabad (Old Delhi), near the Red Fort, another architectural marvel of Shah Jahan’s reign.
  • It remains a functioning mosque and a major historical and cultural landmark of India.

question: Which two important Deccan states were the focus of Shah Jahan's military campaigns?
solution:
• The two important Deccan Sultanates that were the main focus of Shah Jahan’s military campaigns were Bijapur and Golconda.
  • Shah Jahan aimed to expand Mughal control in the Deccan, following the earlier annexation of Ahmednagar in 1632.
  • His campaigns against Bijapur and Golconda were part of a broader strategy to establish full Mughal dominance over the Deccan region.
  • Though complete annexation was not achieved during his reign, both states were forced to accept Mughal suzerainty and pay tribute.
  • These military operations were led by Shah Jahan’s sons, including Aurangzeb, who was appointed viceroy of the Deccan.
  • The efforts laid the groundwork for Aurangzeb’s later full-scale annexation of these states during his reign.

question: Shah Jahan’s reign was known for excessive spending on:
solution:
• Shah Jahan’s reign is especially remembered for its lavish architectural projects.
  • He commissioned the Taj Mahal, one of the most iconic monuments in the world, as a mausoleum for his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
  • Other grand constructions included the Red Fort, Jama Masjid, and the city of Shahjahanabad (Old Delhi).
  • These projects showcased the peak of Mughal architecture and reflected the emperor’s desire for magnificence and legacy.
  • As a result, his reign is marked by excessive spending on architecture and grandeur, rather than military, religious, or educational pursuits.

Additional Information:

  • The architectural style under Shah Jahan saw a fusion of Persian, Islamic, and Indian elements.
  • White marble became a dominant construction material, replacing red sandstone used in earlier Mughal structures.
  • Though the economy initially remained stable, excessive spending later contributed to financial strain on the empire.
  • His successor, Aurangzeb, had to face an already weakened treasury due to the grandeur-focused policies of Shah Jahan.

question: The Mughal painting style under Shah Jahan focused more on:
solution:
• Under Shah Jahan, the Mughal painting style continued to thrive, but with a distinct emphasis on naturalism and individual portraiture.
  • Artists became more focused on realistic depictions of court scenes, royal portraits, and flora/fauna, rather than religious or allegorical themes.
  • The use of subtle colours, refined detailing, and lifelike representations increased during this period.
  • Though not as artistically innovative as during Jahangir’s time, Shah Jahan's era showed refinement and elegance in portraiture.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is naturalism and portraits.

Additional Information:

  • The Mughal atelier (royal workshop) saw the continued presence of master painters, many trained during Jahangir’s time.
  • Paintings often documented imperial ceremonies, court life, processions, and royal hunts.
  • Floral motifs and architectural elements became more stylised, aligning with the aesthetic shift seen in his architectural ventures like the Taj Mahal.
  • While fewer illustrated manuscripts were produced compared to Akbar and Jahangir’s reigns, individual miniatures became more prominent.

question: Shah Jahan's reign saw diplomatic contacts with which foreign power seeking trade rights?
option_3: British East India Company
solution:
• During Shah Jahan’s reign, the British East India Company actively sought to expand its trade privileges in India.
  • They aimed to secure commercial rights, set up factories, and gain more influence over key coastal regions like Surat and Madras.
  • Shah Jahan granted several firmans (royal orders) to the Company, allowing them to operate and trade in certain areas.
  • While diplomatic contact with other powers existed, it was the British East India Company that made significant headway in establishing a foothold during this period.
  • Hence, the correct answer is British East India Company.

Additional Information:

  • The Company sent multiple envoys and representatives during Shah Jahan’s rule to negotiate trade agreements.
  • Notably, Sir Thomas Roe’s mission, though originally during Jahangir’s time, laid the foundation for future British diplomacy.
  • The Mughal court maintained cautious yet beneficial relations with European traders, primarily focusing on economic gain.
  • French and Portuguese presence existed but lacked the sustained diplomatic influence the British achieved in Shah Jahan’s reign.

question: Shah Jahan’s court historian who wrote the Padshahnama was:
solution:
• Abdul Hamid Lahori was the official court historian during the reign of Shah Jahan.
  • He authored the Padshahnama, a detailed chronicle of Shah Jahan’s reign, including military campaigns, architecture, and court life.
  • The work was written in Persian and is considered one of the most valuable historical sources for Shah Jahan’s period.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Abdul Hamid Lahori.

Additional Information:

  • The Padshahnama was commissioned by Shah Jahan himself as an official record of his rule.
  • It followed the tradition of Akbarnama and Ain-i-Akbari written during Akbar’s reign.
  • Lahori’s narrative focused more on glorifying the emperor than critical analysis.

question: The Moti Masjid inside the Agra Fort was built by Shah Jahan using:
solution:
• The Moti Masjid (Pearl Mosque) inside Agra Fort was built by Shah Jahan as a private mosque for the members of the royal court.
  • It is constructed using white marble, which gives it a pristine and elegant appearance.
  • The mosque reflects the refined architectural tastes of Shah Jahan, focusing on symmetry and purity of design.
  • Hence, the correct answer is white marble.

Additional Information:

  • The Moti Masjid was completed around 1654 CE, during the later years of Shah Jahan’s reign.
  • It is known for its three white marble domes and absence of excessive ornamentation, highlighting simplicity and devotion.
  • This mosque is often compared to another Moti Masjid built by Aurangzeb in Delhi.

question: The Mughal treasury faced decline during Shah Jahan’s later years due to:
option_3: War of succession and architectural expenditure
solution:
• In Shah Jahan’s later years, the Mughal treasury began to weaken due to a combination of lavish architectural spending and internal political turmoil.
  • Massive resources were spent on grand constructions like the Taj Mahal and Red Fort, straining the empire’s finances.
  • The onset of the war of succession among his sons further drained the treasury through military mobilisation and administrative instability.
  • Hence, the correct answer is war of succession and architectural expenditure.

Additional Information:

  • The financial decline affected administrative efficiency and made the empire more vulnerable.
  • Shah Jahan’s illness in his later years created a power vacuum, which his sons exploited to fight for the throne.
  • These conflicts set the stage for Aurangzeb’s eventual rise, but at a significant cost to the empire’s wealth and unity.
